questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fibre is given. Identify the area that will be affected by the most common variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

 

Explanation:

The myelin sheath labelled "2" is the most common variant affected in Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS).

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

A group of immune-mediated disorders causing acute paralysis, clinically characterized by weakness starting in the distal limbs and quickly progressing to involve proximal muscle function, resulting in "ascending paralysis”.

Variants

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

  • The most common variant is in Europe & North America.
  • Patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves
  • Antibodies seen:
  • IgG Anti GM1
  • IgG Anti GQ1b

 

Axonal Variants

  • Often associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.
  • More prevalent in China and Japan.

 

Miller Fisher Syndrome

  • Best-recognised variant.
  • Associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.
  • Presents with internal and external ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia

Clinical features

Motor Symptoms:

  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
  • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
  • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
  • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

 

Sensory Symptoms:

  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
  • Difficulty in climbing stairs
  • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

 

Autonomic Symptoms:

  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

Investigations

Lumbar Puncture

  • CSF protein: 100-1000 mg/dL
  • Elevated CSF protein but normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Study Timing

  • Normal CSF findings (<48 hours)
  • Maximum rise of protein seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

  • Prolonged F-wave latencies
  • Earliest finding in AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy)

 

1 (Option A) indicates Schwann cells, which are the supporting cells of the peripheral nervous system and play a crucial role in forming the myelin sheath around the axons. While Schwann cells can be involved in GBS, they are not the primary site of damage in the most common variant, acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (AIDP).

 

3 (Option C) indicates an axon, whose damage can occur in GBS. It is more commonly associated with variants such as acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) or acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN). In the most common AIDP variant, the primary pathology is focused on the myelin sheath rather than the axon itself.

 

4 (Option D) indicates mesaxon, i.e., the region where the inner and outer layers of the Schwann cell membrane meet. It is involved in the formation of the myelin sheath. Although the mesaxon can be affected in GBS, it is not the primary area of damage in the most common AIDP variant.

questions.text: A child presents with visual disturbances and delayed growth. Imaging reveals a suprasellar mass, and histopathology shows the presence of "wet keratin" (compact, eosinophilic anucleate keratin). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

The above history of a child presenting with visual disturbances and delayed growth with imaging features of a suprasellar mass, and histopathology showing the presence of "wet keratin" is suggestive of Craniopharyngioma.

  • Rare, benign CNS tumour
  • Often partly cystic in nature
  • Occurs in the sellar/suprasellar region

Pathophysiology:

  • It can compress normal pituitary tissue and result in pituitary deficiencies, particularly of the anterior pituitary hormones.
  • It can also compress the optic chiasm and also present with hydrocephalus secondary to third ventricle compression.

Clinical Features:

  • Headaches: Due to increased intracranial pressure or meningeal irritation.
  • Visual Disturbances: Temporal hemianopsia is common due to optic chiasm compression.

Endocrine Deficiencies:

  • Growth hormone (GH) deficiency.
  • Gonadotroph, ACTH, TSH, and vasopressin deficiencies.

Other Symptoms: Hydrocephalus, nausea, vomiting, and possible cranial nerve palsies.

Microscopic Examination:

Adamantinomatous Craniopharyngioma (ACP):

  • More common in children.
  • Solid and cystic components.
  • Characterised by squamous epithelium, "wet keratin," and calcifications.

Papillary Craniopharyngioma (PCP):

  • More common in adults.
    • Predominantly solid, with well-differentiated squamous epithelium.
    • Calcifications are rare.

Imaging:

MRI: Preferred modality for detailed evaluation.

  • ACP: Heterogeneous with cystic areas and calcifications.
  • PCP: Solid and less commonly cystic or calcified.

CT: Best for identifying calcifications.

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Medulloblastoma (Option B):

  • Typical location: Midline cerebellum (vermis) in children, not suprasellar.
  • Presentation: Ataxia, gait disturbance, signs of increased intracranial pressure (due to 4th ventricle obstruction) like headache, vomiting, papilledema.
  • Histology: Small, round, blue cells with Homer–Wright rosettes — no wet keratin.
  • This child’s mass is suprasellar, causing visual and endocrine symptoms, which medulloblastomas do not.

Glioma (Option C):

  • Typical types relevant to the optic–hypothalamic region: Optic pathway gliomas, often in children (sometimes with NF1).
  • Presentation: Progressive visual loss, proptosis, and sometimes endocrine dysfunction if the hypothalamus is involved.
  • Histology: Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)–positive spindle cells, eosinophilic Rosenthal fibres (in pilocytic astrocytoma type) — no wet keratin.
  • While location could overlap, the hallmark histologic finding is completely different.

Pituitary Adenoma (Option D):

  • Epidemiology: Very rare in children; it mostly affects adults.
  • Presentation: Endocrine syndromes (hyperprolactinemia, Cushing’s disease, acromegaly), bitemporal hemianopia from optic chiasm compression.
  • Histology: Uniform polygonal pituitary cells in nests or cords; no keratin debris.
  • Age is atypical, histology doesn’t match, and pituitary adenomas don’t show “wet keratin.”

questions.text: A mutation in the SOD1 gene is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

Explanation:

  • The SOD1 gene encodes superoxide dismutase 1, an enzyme responsible for breaking down harmful superoxide radicals into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. This protects cells from oxidative damage.

SOD1 and ALS:

  • Condition: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.
  • Type: SOD1 mutations account for about 20% of familial ALS cases (familial ALS ~10% of all ALS cases).
  • Mechanism:
    • Mutant SOD1 misfolds → gains toxic properties → causes oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction.
    • This leads to degeneration of both upper motor neurons (in motor cortex) and lower motor neurons (in brainstem and spinal cord).

Clinical Features of ALS:

  • Mixed UMN and LMN signs:
    • UMN: Spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign.
    • LMN: Fasciculations, muscle atrophy, weakness.
  • Progressive, usually fatal within 3–5 years (respiratory failure common).
  • Sensation and cognition are usually preserved (helps differentiate from MS or other neuropathies).

Huntington’s disease (Option A): CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene (chromosome 4).

Multiple sclerosis (Option B): Autoimmune demyelination, not linked to SOD1.

Parkinson's disease (Option C): Often linked to mutations in SNCA, LRRK2, PARK genes, not SOD1.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of the vessel due to hypertension
Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms, also known as saccular aneurysms or intracranial aneurysms, most commonly occur due to a defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer of the blood vessel wall.
  • This defect weakens the vessel wall, leading to the formation of a small outpouching or sac-like dilation.
  • These aneurysms are frequently found in the arteries at the base of the brain, particularly at the branching points of the major cerebral arteries.

 

Endothelial injury of vessels due to hypertension (Option A): While hypertension can contribute to the development and progression of aneurysms, it is not the most common cause of berry aneurysms.

Muscle and adventitial layer defect (Option C) and Adventitia defect (Option D): Berry aneurysms primarily involve the defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer.

questions.text: Tau protein inclusions are involved in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alzheimer’s Disease

Explanation:

  • The fundamental abnormality in Alzheimer’s disease is the accumulation of two proteins (Aβ and tau) in specific brain regions in the form of plaques and tangles.

 

Morphology of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Gross: Cortical atrophy (narrowed gyri and widened sulci) is predominant in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
  • Histology:

Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • They are of two types: Diffuse and neuritic (senile).
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.
  • Diffuse plaques are predominantly made up of Aβ 42 and seen in trisomy 21 patients.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.
  • Commonly found in cortical neurons, especially in the entorhinal cortex, and in other sites such as pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, amygdala, basal forebrain, and raphe nuclei.

Hirano bodies
  • Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions are typically found in conditions like Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease.

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.

 

Plaques

Neurofibrillary tangles

Hirano bodies

Granulovacuolar degeneration

Huntington's Disease (Option B) is characterised by toxic gain-of-function of mutant huntingtin protein and neuronal loss in the striatum.

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (Option C) involves the degeneration of motor neurons, often linked to superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutations or TDP-43 protein inclusions.

CNS Lymphoma (Option D) is a type of brain tumour originating from lymphocytes (B cells) and is unrelated to tau protein.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with the development of seizures, for which a CT-guided biopsy was done. The histopathological image showed the presence of psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Meningioma

Explanation:

  • Meningiomas are tumours originating from the meninges, the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. They are not derived from glial cells but rather from the arachnoid cap cells of the meninges.

 

Incorrect Options:

Astrocytoma (Option A) is a GFAP-positive glial cell tumour and the most common primary brain tumour in children. Histologically, it features densely packed elongated cells with round to oval nuclei and prominent nucleoli.

Medulloblastoma (Option B) are embryonal tumours that develop from undifferentiated neuroepithelial cells in the cerebellum. They are not derived from glial cells but instead from primitive neuroectodermal cells. It is the most common malignant tumour in children.

Ependymoma (Option D) arises from ependymal cells lining the ventricular system or spinal cord. It is commonly seen in the fourth ventricle in children and in the spinal cord in adults. Histologically, it is characterised by perivascular pseudorosettes, where tumour cells are arranged around blood vessels, and ependymal rosettes, where cells form true rosettes with a central lumen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schwannoma

Explanation:

Schwannoma is a benign tumour of the peripheral nerve sheath, characterised by spindle-shaped cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, which are pathognomonic.

  • Schwannomas are benign tumours originating from Schwann cells, often linked to mutations in the NF2 gene.
  • These tumours are well-circumscribed, encapsulated, and typically attached loosely to nerves, allowing for surgical removal without damaging nerve function.
  • They appear as firm, grey masses.
  • Histology:
    • Antoni A areas: Dense eosinophilic regions with spindle cells in intersecting fascicles.
    • Antoni B areas: Looser, hypocellular regions with a myxoid extracellular matrix.
    • Verocay bodies: Structures with central "nuclear-free zones" surrounded by palisading nuclei.
    • Schwann cells show spindle-shaped nuclei and immunoreactivity for S-100.

 

  • Degenerative changes:
    • Nuclear pleomorphism, xanthomatous change, and necrosis can occur.
    • Malignant transformation is rare, but large mitotically active schwannomas can resemble sarcomas.
  • Other features:
    • Schwannomas may recur if incompletely resected but rarely transform malignantly.
    • They can arise from sensory nerves, including branches of the trigeminal nerve or dorsal roots, and can occur both within and outside the nerve trunk.
    • Surgical removal is typically curative.

 

Neurofibroma (Option B) are benign tumours that develop from peripheral nerves. They are composed of a mix of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and other cellular components. Histologically, neurofibromas have a more varied appearance than schwannomas, with multiple cell types and no presence of Verocay bodies.

Neuroma (Option C) is an abnormal growth of nerve tissue caused by nerve injury or trauma. They are characterised by disorganised nerve fibres and can lead to symptoms such as pain, tingling, and sensory disturbances.

Glioma (Option D) are tumours that arise from glial cells in the central nervous system.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same core pathology, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alzheimer’s disease

Explanation:

Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and multisystem atrophy are all associated with alpha-synuclein pathology, specifically the formation of Lewy bodies in the brain.

In contrast, Alzheimer's disease is primarily characterized by the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles of tau protein, representing a different core pathology.

Parkinson’s Disease (PD):

  • Genetic Basis:
    • Autosomal Dominant PD: Caused by mutations in SNCA, which encodes α-synuclein, the key component of Lewy bodies.
    • Autosomal Recessive PD: Linked to mutations in DJ-1, PINK1, and Parkin.
    • Most Common Autosomal Dominant Mutation: LRRK2 (Leucine-Rich Repeat Kinase 2).
  • Clinical Features: Triad of Tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross pathology: Pallor of the substantia nigra due to neuronal loss.
    • Microscopic features:
      • Lewy bodies: Cytoplasmic, eosinophilic inclusions, either single or multiple.
      • Structure: Dense core surrounded by a pale halo.
      • Ultrastructure: Composed of fine filaments of α-synuclein.

 

 

Protein

Associated Disease(s)

Aβ (Amyloid-beta)

Alzheimer disease

Tau

Alzheimer's disease, Frontotemporal lobar degeneration

LRRK2 mutations

Parkinson disease

α-synuclein

Parkinson's disease, Multiple system atrophy

TPD-43

Frontotemporal lobar degeneration, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

FUS

Frontotemporal lobar degeneration, Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

Polyglutamine aggregates

Huntington's disease, Some forms of spinocerebellar ataxia, Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy

Tau (with other symptoms)

Progressive supranuclear palsy, Corticobasal degeneration, Chronic traumatic encephalopathy

questions.text: A patient presents with a hand lesion, and the histopathology of the lesion is provided. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It originates from the peripheral nerve
Verrocay bodies are seen in light microscopy
It is malignant and often metastasizes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is malignant and often metastasizes

Explanation:

The described scenario, featuring a hand lesion and histopathological findings of encapsulated tissue with areas of dense cellularity and loose myxoid regions, suggests a diagnosis of Schwannoma.

 

  • Schwannomas are benign tumours exhibiting Schwann cell differentiation and originate directly from peripheral nerves. (Option A)
  • It is associated with NF2 mutations on chromosome 22, producing merlin. (Option C)
  • Most common location: Cerebellopontine angle
  • Microscopically, they are comprised of:
    • Antoni A area: Dense eosinophilic areas containing spindle cells are arranged into intersecting fascicles, leading to nuclei palisading. The resulting structures with central “nuclear-free zones” are called Verocay bodies. (Option B)
    • Antoni B area: Loose, hypocellular areas where a myxoid extracellular matrix spreads apart the spindle cells.

  • It typically shows immunoreactivity to S-100.
  • Clinical features:
    • Cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures (e.g., brainstem or spinal cord).
    • Mostly occurs at the cerebellopontine angle (attached to the vestibular branch of the 8th nerve).
    • Presents with tinnitus and hearing loss
    • Sensory nerves are involved (trigeminal nerve and dorsal roots).
    • They can arise in association with large nerve trunks or as soft tissue lesions (extradural)

Management: Surgical removal is curative.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. The investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumour. Which of the following histological findings correlates with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumour cells

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation of a dural-based tumour with raised intracranial pressure suggests a diagnosis of meningioma, and the histological feature of psammoma bodies with whorling of tumour cells is a characteristic finding.
  • They originate from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid layer and are typically connected to the dura mater.
  • More common in women and has increased risk with pregnancy, exposure to radiation and NF2 gene mutation.
  • Tumours typically exhibit a rubbery dural mass, compressing the brain, yet easily separable.
  • Histopathologically, they present with a whorled pattern of cells and psammoma bodies and are progesterone receptor-positive.

Incorrect Options:

Fried-egg appearance (Option A) is characteristic of oligodendrogliomas along with chicken wire vessels, calcification and perineuronal satellitosis.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (Option B) are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells and are seen in retinoblastomas, along with Homer-Wright rosettes, undifferentiated tumour cells and areas of necrosis and calcification.


Homer-Wright rosettes (Option D) are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes. They are commonly seen in neuroblastomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe headaches, seizures, and progressive neurological deficits. Imaging reveals a large mass with areas of necrosis and irregular borders in the brain. The biopsy confirms the diagnosis of a malignant tumor. Which of the following options represents the most common type of brain tumor in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glioblastoma:

  • Glioblastoma, also known as glioblastoma multiforme, is the most common and aggressive type of malignant brain tumor in adults. It originates from glial cells, which are supportive cells in the brain. Glioblastomas often have a rapid growth rate and infiltrative behavior and tend to be resistant to conventional treatments. The symptoms mentioned in the question, such as severe headaches, seizures, and progressive neurological deficits, are characteristic of glioblastoma due to its invasive nature and effect on brain function.
  • Glioblastoma accounts for about 80% of primary brain tumors in adults.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastoma is a type of malignant brain tumor, but it is more commonly found in children rather than adults. It usually arises in the cerebellum, which is the part of the brain responsible for coordinating movement.

Option B - Meningioma: Meningiomas are generally benign tumors that arise from the meninges, which are the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. While they can occur in adults, they are usually slow-growing and tend to be less aggressive than glioblastomas.

Option C - Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a rare type of eye cancer that primarily affects young children. It originates in the retina, which is the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. It does not typically present as a brain tumor and is not commonly seen in adults

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes. Imaging reveals characteristic amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain. On further investigation, the accumulation of a specific protein is found to be a hallmark of this disease. What is the protein responsible for the amyloidosis seen in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amyloid beta protein: In Alzheimer's disease, there is an accumulation of abnormal proteins, including beta-amyloid plaques and tau protein neurofibrillary tangles, in the brain. These amyloid plaques are primarily composed of beta-amyloid protein, which is derived from the amyloid precursor protein (APP). The accumulation of beta-amyloid protein is a hallmark feature of Alzheimer's disease and is believed to play a role in the pathogenesis of the condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ATTR (Transthyretin Amyloidosis): Transthyretin amyloidosis is a disease characterized by the buildup of abnormal transthyretin proteins, primarily in the nerves and heart, not in the brain. It is not associated with Alzheimer's disease.

Option C - Amyloid Beta 2 Protein: Amyloid beta protein is typically referred to as amyloid beta (Aβ) or amyloid beta protein 1-42 (Aβ42) in the context of Alzheimer's disease. There isn't a commonly recognized "Amyloid beta 2" protein associated with Alzheimer's disease.

Option D - Acal: Acal does not correspond to any known protein associated with Alzheimer's disease or amyloidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the disorder associated with hexanucleotide repeat?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Frontotemporal dementia

Explanation:

  • The disorder associated with hexanucleotide repeat is Frontotemporal dementia or Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (FTLD).
  • These are a heterogeneous group of disorders associated with focal degeneration of frontal and/or temporal lobes.
  • They are associated with cellular inclusions comprised of specific proteins; the two most common patterns are:

Features

FTLD-tau

FTLD-TDP

Inclusions

Cytoplasmic tau inclusions

Inclusions contain TDP-43 (RNA-binding protein)

Associated mutations

Associated with mutations in the MAPT gene (encoding tau)
  • Expansion of a hexanucleotide repeat in the 5′ region of C9orf72.
  • Mutations in the TARDBP gene (encoding TDP-43)
  • Mutations in the GRN gene

The below-mentioned disorders are Trinucleotide Repeat Disorders, where there is excessive repetition of trinucleotides.

  • In Introns/Non-coding region:
    • Fragile X syndrome: CGG (Option A ruled out)
    • Friedreich ataxia: GAA
    • Myotonic dystrophy: CTG (Option C ruled out)
  • In Exons/ Coding region:

Huntington's disease: CAG (Mnemonic- Hunter in a Cage) (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a lesion in the right eye. Histopathology reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • The presence of a lesion in the right eye and histopathological findings of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes strongly suggest a diagnosis of Retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma

It is caused by the inactivation of both alleles of the RB1 tumour suppressor gene.

Types

  • Heritable (germline):
    • It frequently leads to bilateral retinoblastoma and is caused by a germline mutation in the RB1 gene in all cells, followed by a somatic mutation in the retinal cells.
    • Affected individuals are also at increased risk for developing non-ocular tumours, such as osteosarcoma.
  • Non-heritable (sporadic):
    • This form typically presents as a unilateral tumour and results from two somatic mutations in the retinal cells occurring after embryonic development, without a germline mutation.
    • It is not inherited and does not carry an increased risk of developing non-ocular tumours.

Clinical features
  • Occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age (most common ocular neoplasm in children).
  • Leukocoria: White pupillary reflex (most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma).
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye
  • Poor vision
  • Asymptomatic

Fundus examination

A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma

Genetic testing

RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells.
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes.
  • Undifferentiated tumour cells.
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification.

 

Optic nerve glioma (Option B) is a benign tumour that arises from the glial cells of the optic nerve. It is most commonly seen in children and is often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Symptoms may include vision loss, proptosis, and visual field defects. It typically occurs along the optic nerve and does not exhibit Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant soft tissue sarcoma that originates from skeletal muscle cells or their precursors. It is most common in children and can occur in various locations, including the head and neck, genitourinary tract, and extremities. Symptoms depend on the tumour's location but often include a painless mass or swelling. It affects the eye but does not show these characteristic rosettes.

Ocular melanoma (Option D) is a rare malignant tumour that develops in the pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) of the eye, most commonly in the choroid (part of the eye's vascular layer). It is more common in adults and can lead to symptoms like vision changes, dark spots in the field of vision, and proptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Αβ 40 and 42:

  • αβ 40 and 42 are amyloid-beta peptides that are deposited in the brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease, forming plaques.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Synuclein: This is associated with Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

Option C - Polyglutamine: This is associated with Huntington's disease.

Option D - FUS: This is associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

questions.text: In the WHO grading of astrocytoma, which grade does glioblastoma fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IV:

  • In the WHO classification of astrocytoma, glioblastoma falls under Grade IV.
  • This is the highest grade, and it means that the tumor is very bad and growing quickly.
  • Glioblastoma is also called a grade IV astrocytoma.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Apo E4:

  • The ApoE4 variant of the Apo E gene is considered a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.
  • The presence of ApoE4 is associated with a higher likelihood of developing Alzheimer's disease and contribute to an earlier onset of the condition.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, B, and C are not a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.
